Field Label: Record ID
Check all that apply: Categorizes all food into good" or "bad""
Check all that apply: Thinks excessively about the fat content of food
Check all that apply: Thinks excessively about the caloric content of food
Check all that apply: Thinks excessively about the sugar content of food
Check all that apply: Fears that eating a certain type of food will lead to immediate body changes, e.g. eating fat will deposit fat to hips
Check all that apply: Fear of eating from a full plate of food
Check all that apply: Fear of eating all of the food that is on a plate of food
Check all that apply: Fear of consuming fluids
Check all that apply: Fear of not being able to consume fluids
Check all that apply: Fear of being unable to eat
Check all that apply: Fear of being unable to stop eating

Check all that apply: Fear of eating in front of other people (note: this can reflect fear that others will regard the subjects' eating negatively because they are so fat or this can also involve magical thinking such as absorbing calories that other people eat)
Check all that apply: Fear of being fat or overweight
Check all that apply: Fear of weighing outside of a narrow range or preoccupation with a specific weight
Check all that apply: Excessive concern with a specific body part or aspect of appearance
Check all that apply: Fear of others thinking she is fat
Check all that apply: Excessive concern with size of clothing, e.g. would not buy clothing that was not a size 3 even if it fit and looked good
Check all that apply: Fear of wearing certain types of clothing, e.g. fear of wearing underwear
Check all that apply: Fear of wearing either tight or loose fitting clothing
Check all that apply: Hoarding food preoccupations
Check all that apply: Exercise preoccupations
Check all that apply: Other preoccupations
Check all that apply: Need to consume food at a specific rate, e.g. can take a bite only every 2 minutes
Check all that apply: Need to chew each mouthful of food a specific number of times
Check all that apply: Need to cut each piece of food into a specific size
Check all that apply: Need to consume only certain colors or types of foods
Check all that apply: Need to avoid certain types of foods, e.g. fats, meats
Check all that apply: Need to consume each food type completely and in a specific order, e.g. must eat all green beans before potatoes can be eaten
Check all that apply: Need to consume fluids in a certain way or amount, e.g. need to drink 2 glasses of water before eating any meal
Check all that apply: Need to eat meals by oneself
Check all that apply: Need to leave food on the plate when done eating, cannot consume all food on plate
Check all that apply: Need to manipulate or stir food
Check all that apply: Need to fill glass or plate only partially, cannot fill glass or plate fully
Check all that apply: Need to have the table set in a specific way before she can eat
Check all that apply: Need to wipe mouth with napkin a fixed number of times after each bite of food
Check all that apply: Food cannot touch lips
Check all that apply: No part of the body can touch the table or plate
Check all that apply: Need for absolute constancy of food expected, e.g. an orange could not be substituted if an apple was expected
Check all that apply: Need to compute caloric content of all foods eaten
Check all that apply: Need to compute fat content of all foods eaten
Check all that apply: Need to cook for others
Check all that apply: Need to begin each binge with a certain type of food or with food of a certain color
Check all that apply: Need to eat only a certain type(s) of food
Check all that apply: Need to eat all food that is present (can leave no food uneaten no matter what it is)
Check all that apply: Need to purge in a specific way or position, e.g. must use 2 fingers
Check all that apply: Need to purge a specific minimum amount
Check all that apply: Need to purge a specific amount of time after eating
Check all that apply: Need to use a specific number of laxatives
Check all that apply: Need to purge in a specific place
Check all that apply: Need to have thighs not touch while sitting or standing
Check all that apply: Need to continually check that wrist can be spanned with fingers
Check all that apply: Need to feel hip bones repeatedly
Check all that apply: Need to see a specific bone, e.g. wrist
Check all that apply: Ritualized bathroom habits, e.g. pushing on lower stomach when urinating or defecating
Check all that apply: Need to overdress to force sweating
Check all that apply: Need to repeatedly weigh oneself or to repeatedly check one's weight
Check all that apply: Need to weigh oneself only in ritualize ways, e.g. nude, at 8 AM, after meals or defecating
Check all that apply: Need to exercise after meals
Check all that apply: Need to exercise in a specific way and/or at a specific time, e.g. can only do sit-ups at 7 AM and run at 4 PM
Check all that apply: Ritualized exercise pattern, e.g. must do 50 sit-ups, if interrupted while doing the 49th must begin over again and do all 50.
Check all that apply: Need to be moving at all times, cannot sit still, paces, fidgets
Check all that apply: Need to shiver to expend calories rather than putting on additional clothing
Check all that apply: Hoarding food in a ritualized way.
Check all that apply: Collecting and saving recipes, pictures of food, articles on food
Check all that apply: Lists of body weight
Check all that apply: Lists of caloric intake
Check all that apply: Other
How much of your time, including meal times, is occupied by the preoccupations?
Choices, Calculations, OR Slider Labels: 0 , None|1 , Mild, less than 1 hr/day or occasional intrusion|2 , Moderate, 1 to 3 hrs/day or frequent intrusion|3 , Severe, greater than 3 and up to 8 hrs/day or very frequent intrusion|4 , Extreme, greater than 8 hrs/day or near constant intrusion

Field Label: [When preoccupations occur as brief, intermittent intrusions, it may be difficult to assess time occupied by them in terms of total hours. In such cases, estimate time by determining how frequently they occur. Consider both the number of times the intrusions occur and how many hours of the day are affected. Ask:] How frequently do the preoccupations occur?

Field Label: Are these preoccupations consistent with the way you see yourself? [Probe: acceptance, alien, etc.]
Choices, Calculations, OR Slider Labels: 0 , The preoccupations are ego dystonic. Patient has fully accepted them as an integrated part of his/her personality

Field Label: How much of an effort do you make to resist the preoccupations? How often do you try to disregard or turn your attention away from these thoughts as they enter your mind? [Only rate effort made to resist, not success or failure in actually controlling the preoccupations. Note that this item does not directly measure the severity of the intrusive thoughts; rather it rates a manifestation of health, i.e., the effort the patient makes to counteract the preoccupations by means other than avoidance or the performance of rituals. Consider use of behavioral techniques as a form of resistance.]
Choices, Calculations, OR Slider Labels: 0 , Makes an effort to always resist or symptoms so minimal patient feels no need to resist them|1 , Tries to resist most of the time|2 , Makes some effort to resist|3 , Yields to all preoccupations without attempting to control them, but does so with reluctance|4 , Completely and willingly yields to all preoccupations

Field Label: How much of an effort do you make to resist the preoccupations? How often do you try to disregard or turn your attention away from these thoughts as they enter your mind? [Only rate effort made to resist, not success or failure in actually controlling the preoccupations. Note that this item does not directly measure the severity of the intrusive thoughts; rather it rates a manifestation of health, i.e., the effort the patient makes to counteract the preoccupations by means other than avoidance or the performance of rituals. Consider use of behavioral techniques as a form of resistance.]
Choices, Calculations, OR Slider Labels: 0 , Makes an effort to always resist or symptoms so minimal patient feels no need to resist them|1 , Tries to resist most of the time|2 , Makes some effort to resist|3 , Yields to all preoccupations without attempting to control them, but does so with reluctance|4 , Completely and willingly yields to all preoccupations

Field Label: How much control do you have over your preoccupations? How successful are you in stopping or diverting your preoccupations? Can you dismiss them? [In contrast to he preceding item on resistance, the ability of the patient to control her/his preoccupation is more closely related to the severity of the intrusive thoughts.]
Choices, Calculations, OR Slider Labels: 0 , Complete control|1 , Much control, usually able to stop or divert preoccupations with some effort and concentration|2 , Moderate control, sometimes able to stop or divert preoccupations|3 , Little control, rarely successful in stopping or dismissing preoccupations, can only divert attention with difficulty|4 , No control, experienced as completely involuntary, rarely able to even momentarily alter the thinking.

Field Label: How much control do you have over your preoccupations? How successful are you in stopping or diverting your preoccupations? Can you dismiss them? [In contrast to he preceding item on resistance, the ability of the patient to control her/his preoccupation is more closely related to the severity of the intrusive thoughts.]
Choices, Calculations, OR Slider Labels: 0 , Complete control|1 , Much control, usually able to stop or divert preoccupations with some effort and concentration|2 , Moderate control, sometimes able to stop or divert preoccupations|3 , Little control, rarely successful in stopping or dismissing preoccupations, can only divert attention with difficulty|4 , No control, experienced as completely involuntary, rarely able to even momentarily alter the thinking.

Field Label: Do you think that your preoccupations are reasonable or make sense? [Rate patient's insight into the senselessness or excessiveness of her/his preoccupation(s) as compared with normal people.]
Choices, Calculations, OR Slider Labels: 0 , Excellent insight, fully rational. Sees the preoccupations a senseless and excessive OR sees them as neither senseless nor excessive because they are reasonably so minimal|1 , Good insight. Readily acknowledges absurdity or excessiveness of the preoccupations but does not seem completely convinced that there isn't something to be concerned about|2 , Fair insight. Reluctantly admits thoughts seem unreasonable or excessive, but wavers. May have some unrealistic fears, but no fixed convictions|3 , Poor insight. Maintains that thoughts are not unreasonable  or excessive, but acknowledges validity of contrary evidence  |4 , Lack insight. Definitely convinced that thoughts are reasonable and not excessive. Patient is unresponsive to contrary evidence

Field Label: Do you think that your preoccupations are reasonable or make sense? [Rate patient's insight into the senselessness or excessiveness of her/his preoccupation(s) as compared with normal people.]
Choices, Calculations, OR Slider Labels: 0 , Excellent insight, fully rational. Maintains that thoughts are not unreasonable  or excessive, but acknowledges validity of contrary evidence  |4 , Lack insight. Definitely convinced that thoughts are reasonable and not excessive. Patient is unresponsive to contrary evidence

Field Label: Would you like to change so that you would no longer be bothered by these preoccupations?
[If the answer is yes :] How much effort would you expend to make such changes?
Choices, Calculations, OR Slider Labels: 0 , Patient desperately wants to stop the preoccupations and reports a willingness to do anything to stop them OR preoccupations are so minimal that it is reasonable to not want to stop them|1 , Patient does want to stop the thoughts and is willing to work to some degree to do so|2 , Patient states that she would not like to be bothered by the  thoughts but does not seem willing to do very much toward that goal  |3 , The patient would like to diminish the impact of the thoughts but does not say that she would like the preoccupations to totally disappear|4 , The patient does not wish to stop having the preoccupations  (Thoughts may actually be comforting and reassuring)

Field Label: Row strong is the drive to perform the rituals? [Pause] How much control do you have over the rituals? [In contrast to the preceding item on resistance, the ability of the patient to control her/his need to perform the ritual(s) is more closely related to the severity of the rituals.]
Choices, Calculations, OR Slider Labels: 0 , Complete control|1, Much control experiences pressure to perform the behavior but usually able to exercise voluntary control over it|2 , Moderate control, strong pressure to perform the behavior , can control it only with difficulty|3 , Little control, very strong drive to perform behavior , must be carried to completion, can only delay with difficulty|4 , No control, drive to perform behavior experienced as completely involuntary and overpowering , rarely able to momentarily delay activity

Choices, Calculations, OR Slider Labels: 0 , Complete control|1 , Much control experiences pressure to perform the behavior but usually able to exercise voluntary control over it|2 , Moderate control, strong pressure to perform the behavior , can control it only with difficulty|3 , Little control, very strong drive to perform behavior , must be carried to completion, can only delay with difficulty|4 , No control, drive to perform behavior experienced as completely involuntary and overpowering , rarely able to momentarily delay activity

Field Label: Do you think that your rituals are reasonable or make sense? Rate patient's insight into the senselessness or excessiveness of her/his rituals as compared with normal people.
Choices, Calculations, OR Slider Labels: 0 , Excellent insight, fully rational. Sees the rituals as senseless and excessive OR sees them as neither senseless nor excessive because they are so reasonably minimal|1 , Good insight. Readily acknowledges absurdity or excessiveness of the rituals but does not seem completely convinced that there isn't something to be concerned about|2 , Fair insight. Reluctantly admits behaviors seem unreasonable or excessive, but wavers. May have some unrealistic fears, but no fixed convictions|3 , Poor insight. Maintains that behaviors are not unreasonable or excessive, but acknowledges the validity of contrary evidence|4 , Lack insight. Definitely convinced that behaviors are reasonable and not excessive. Patient is unresponsive to contrary evidence

Field Label: Would you like to change so that you would no longer be bothered by these rituals?
[If the answer is yes, ask:] How much effort would you expend to make such changes?
Choices, Calculations, OR Slider Labels: 0 , Patient desperately wants to stop the rituals and reports a willingness to do anything to stop them OR rituals are so minimal that it is reasonable to not want to stop them|1 , Patient does want to stop the rituals and is willing to work to some degree to do so|2 , Patient states that she would not like to be bothered by the rituals but does not seem willing to do very much toward that goal|3 , The patient would like to diminish the impact of the rituals but does not say that she would like them to totally disappear. Further, she seems unwilling to be very active in making the Change|4 , The patient expresses no interest in stopping the rituals (The rituals may actually be comforting and reassuring)

Field Label: Have you been avoiding doing anything, going any place, or being with anyone because of y our preoccupations or out of concern you will perform your rituals?

[If yes, ask:] How much do you avoid? (Rate degree to which patient deliberately tries to avoid things. Consider the frequency of occurrence of situations to be avoided; i.e. if circumstance is infrequent but always avoided, she would score a 1 not a 4. Sometimes rituals are designed to 'avoid' contact with something the patient fears - this would not be considered avoidance.]
Choices, Calculations, OR Slider Labels: 0 , No deliberate avoidance|1 , Mild, minimal avoidance|2 , Moderate, some avoidance clearly present|3 , Severe, much avoidance; avoidance prominent|4 , Extreme, very extensive avoidance; patient does almost everything she can to avoid triggering symptoms
